title: A novel magnetic metal organic framework nanocomposite for extraction and preconcentration of heavy metal ions, and its optimization via experimental design methodology
text: Heavy metal ions are toxic pollutants which exist in wastewaters and their presence concerns industries and environmental organizations all over the world. Most of these pollutants are very toxic and dangerous for human health. Thus determination of trace amounts of heavy metals is often a major task for the analytical chemists, as it is a good tool for the identification and monitoring of toxicants in environmental samples. Among heavy metals that exist in the environment, cadmium monitoring is very vital due to the fact that cadmium concentrations in the environment are increasing dramatically [
]. Cadmium exposure can be linked to diseases associated with aging such as osteoporosis, prostate, and pancreatic cancer [
]. Lead is one of the most toxic and hazardous elements in human health, because it can cause detrimental effect on metabolic processes of human beings [

]. It has been proven to be a carcinogenic agent. One of the heavy metals is nickel which is toxic. Aspiration of its derivatives can lead to serious problems, including nasopharynx, lung and dermatological diseases and malignant tumors [
]. Moreover, nickel can cause skin disorder, known as nickel-eczema which is a considerable health problem exclusively among women [
]. Zinc deficiency might lead to several disorders such as growth retardation, diarrhea, immunity depression, eye and skin lesions, malfunction of wound healing, and other skin diseases [

]. Though trace amounts of metals such as zinc are biotic for humans, the excess utilization can be harmful and toxic, so it should be used in the case of physiological needs. Thus the determination of trace amounts of heavy metals is one of the most important topics in analytical chemistry.
Various instrumental techniques, including electrothermal atomic absorption spectrometry (ETAAS) [

] have been used for the determination of heavy metals. Since the heavy metals concentration level in environmental samples is fairly low and the complexity of matrices is a main problem; thus preconcentration techniques are often required [
]. Different procedures such as: liquid-liquid extraction (LLE) [
], and solid phase extraction (SPE) have been developed for the extraction and preconcentration of heavy metals in natural matrices [

Among mentioned methods, the most commonly used technique for the preconcentration of heavy metal ions from environmental samples is solid phase extraction. Its common application is due to its simplicity, rapidity, minimal cost, and low consumption of reagents [
]. By the advent of SPE, various diverse sorbents have been utilized such as carbon nanotubes [

]. Porous materials are defined as solids containing empty voids which can host other molecules. The fundamental features of these materials are their porosity, the ratio between total occupied and empty space, the (average) size of the pores and the surface area. Typical surface area values for the porous materials applied in technological processes range between 2,000 and 8,000 m

]. The most important applications of such materials are the storage of small molecules and filtering .The metal organic frameworks are defined as a nanocomposite material which can be consisted of either inorganic or organic materials. MOFs have shown high potential in gas storage, separation, chemical sensing, drug delivery, and heterogeneous catalysis applications [

]. In general, the flexible and highly porous structure of MOFs allows guest species such as metal ions to diffuse into their bulk structure. The shape and size of the pores lead to selectivity over the guests that may be adsorbed. These features make MOFs an ideal sorbent in solid phase extraction of heavy metals. However, there is little information about MOFs as an adsorbent [
In this work for the first time a magnetic metal organic framework immobilized with Fe

–Dithizone has been utilized as a novel adsorbent for the fast separation and the preconcentration of Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II) ions in various matrixes. The magnetic sorbent was characterized by, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), thermogravimetry (TG), and differential thermal analysis (DTA). The magnetic property of the sorbent causes a rapid and easy separation of the new solid phase from the solution. The presence of dithizone in the sorbent helps the new solid phase to show selectivity towards these heavy metals. Also MOF cavities can increase the surface area and adsorption capacity of this new sorbent. A Box–Behnken design was used in order to find the optimum conditions of the method through response surface methodology. Finally, the sorbent was used for the preconcentration and determination of Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II) ions in different real samples and satisfactory results were obtained.
All reagents of analytical grade (dithizone, Cu(OAc)

, NaOH, KCl, thiourea, 3-choloropropyltriethoxysilane,benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate (BTC), toluene, triethylamine, ethanol, dimethylformamide, methanol and acetone) were purchased from Merck (Darmstadt, Germany,
) and were used without further purification. Standard solutions of 1,000 mg L
of Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II), Zn(II), were purchased from Merck (Darmstadt, Germany,
). All solutions were prepared using double distilled water.

AA-680 Shimadzu (Kyoto, Japan) flame atomic absorption spectrometer with a deuterium background corrector was used for the determination of Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II) ions. Cadmium, lead, Nickel and Zinc hollow cathode lamps (HCL) were used as the radiation sources with wavelengths of 228.8, 283.3, 232.0 and 213.9 nm, respectively. All measurements were carried out in an air/acetylene flame. The pH of the solutions were measured at 25 ± 1 °C with a digital WTW Metrohm 827 Ion analyzer (Herisau, Switzerland) equipped with a combined glass-calomelelectrode. CHN analysis was performed on a Thermo Finnigan Flash EA112 elemental analyzer (Okehampton, UK). IR spectra were recorded by a Bruker IFS-66 FT-IR Spectrophotometer (Bruker,

). High-angle X-ray diffraction patterns were obtained using a Philips-PW 17C diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (Philips PW, The Netherlands). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed by gently distributing the sample powder on the stainless steel stubs, using an SEM (KYKY- 3200, Beijing, China) instrument. Thermogravimetry and differential thermal analyses (TGA/DTA) were carried out on a Bahr STA-503 (
Standard reference material was digested with 6 mL of HCl (37 % (v/v)) and 2 mL of HNO

(65 % (v/v)) in a microwave digestion system. Digestion was carried out for 2 min at 250 W, 2 min at 0 W, 6 min at 250 W, 5 min at 400 W, 8 min at 550 W, and then venting for 8 min. The digestion residue was then diluted with double distilled water [
, Ca(II), Mn(II), Fe(III), Cu(II), Al(III), Hg(II), Co(II), Sb(III), AsO
solution. The working standard solutions were prepared by diluting an appropriate amount of the stock solution with double distilled water. All of these solutions were stored in ambient temperature.
Synthesis of magnetic metal-organic framework nanocomposite
nanoparticles were synthesized according to our previously reported procedure [
]. It was then modified with 3-choloropropyltriethoxysilane. In a typical reaction, 1.0 g of Fe
was suspended in 50 mL toluene, and the mixture was stirred for 1 h. Then 3-choloro-propyltriethoxysilane (2.0 g) was added to the mixture and it was refluxed for 12 h under nitrogen atmosphere [

]. The obtained solid was suspended in 100 mL of a mixture containing triethylamine and toluene (1:1 v/v) and an excess amount of dithizone (10.0 g) was added. After 24 h reflux the red solid was removed from the solvents by centrifugation, washed with methanol and acetone and then dried at room temperature (Fig.
-DHz) was characterized by IR spectroscopy, high-angle X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy, elemental and thermal analysis.
) A schematic diagram of dithizone functionalized Fe
) The schematic illustration of synthesized magnetic MOF-DHz nanocomposite
MOF was synthesized according to the previously reported procedure [
]. A solution containing 0.84 g of trimesic acid and 1.75 g of Cu(NO

O in 50 mL of ethanol was refluxed under vigorous stirring. After a few hours, a blue solid started to precipitate. The resulting solid was kept under reflux conditions for 48 h, and subsequently cooled at room temperature. The obtained blue powder was recovered by centrifugation, washed once with water and then ethanol for the second time. Afterwards, it was dried under vacuum at 100 °C for 12 h and kept under dry nitrogen until further use (sample A). The synthesized MOF was characterized by IR spectroscopy, TG, DTA, SEM, and XRD.
Synthesis of magnetic metal-organic framework nanocomposite
Magnetic metal-organic framework nanocomposite was synthesized according to the following procedure (Fig.
BTC (0.5 g) was dissolved in a mixture of DMF/ethanol (1:1, 80 mL). Thereafter 25 mL of an ethanol solution containing 0.2 g Fe

-DHz was prepared. Then, 2 mL (for sample B), 6 mL (for sample C) and 10 mL (for sample D) were added to the mixture under magnetic stirring, and it was heated to 70 °C. After the addition of 40 mL Cu(OAc)

O (0.86 g, 4.31 mmol) aqueous solution to the reaction mixture, the reaction was carried out at 70 °C along with stirring for a further 4 h. Finally, the product was isolated from the supernatant solution by magnetic decantation and washed with water (50 mL) and ethanol (10 mL × 3). Magnetic sorbent was characterized by IR spectroscopy, TG, DTA, SEM, TEM and XRD.

Extraction of heavy metal ions from aqueous solutions was investigated by batch analysis. Uptakes were performed in test tubes containing 15 μg of Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II) ions in 15 mL of double distilled water. According to a preliminary experimental design, the pH of the solutions were adjusted by the drop wise addition of 1 mol L

hydrochloric acid. Then magnetic sorbent was added into the solutions. After that, the mixture was stirred for an appropriate time to extract these heavy metal ions from the solution completely. Finally, the test tubes were exposed to a strong magnet (15 cm × 12 cm × 5 cm, 0.8 T), where permanent magnet in the wall caused the particles to aggregate on one side of the test tube. The adsorbed amounts of Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II) ions were determined using FAAS due to the concentration change for these ions in solution after adsorption. The instrument response was periodically checked with known Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II) ions standard solutions. Extraction percentage for each ion was calculated using the following equation:
are initial and final concentrations (mg L
) of each ion in the solution, respectively. In the elution step, 7.8 mL of a 0.9 mol L

NaOH solution as an eluent was added to the magnetic sorbent and shaken. This mixture was again exposed to a strong magnet and the clear solution of eluent, containing the eluted heavy metal ions was introduced to FAAS in order to determine the amount of each ion.

The method was successfully used for the determination of Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II) and Zn(II) ions in distilled, tap, river, sea and mineral water. River water sample was collected from the south of Tehran, sea water sample from the Caspian Sea (North of Iran), and mineral water sample from Sarcheshme Mine (Kerman, Iran). The samples were filtered through nylon filters (Millipore) and were stored in cleaned polyethylene bottles. Tap and distilled water samples were taken from our research laboratory with no further pretreatment. Before the SPE procedure, the pH of the samples was adjusted to 6.4 according to the optimized experimental conditions.

Fish and sediment samples were collected from two different sites in Moosa creek. Moosa creek is located in the Northwest of the Persian Gulf (in the south of Iran), and has several subsidiary creeks. Among them, Jafar creek was chosen as a polluted site and Behad creek as a reference site since it is far from petrochemical industries. The fish samples (platycephalus indicus) were placed in an ice, transferred to the laboratory and stored at −20 °C prior to analysis. Fish samples were dissected with a clean plastic knife and a part of the muscle was taken out quickly. Then it was dried in an oven at 70 °C for 48 h. Analysis were performed according to the procedure reported by Yilmaz (2003) [
]. A porcelain mortar was used to grind dry tissues. 0.5 g of each sample was digested with 5 mL of concentrated HNO

in Teflon beakers for 4 h at 100 °C. The content was filtered into a 25 mL standard volumetric flask and was diluted up to 25 mL with double distillated water. Sediment samples were collected from using a Peterson grab sampler, stored in a plastic bag in ice, transferred to the laboratory and kept at −20 °C before analysis. 1.0 g of these samples was digested with 6 mL of HCl (37 %) and 2 mL of HNO

(65 %) in a microwave digestion system. Digestion was carried out for 2 min at 250 W, 2 min at 0 W, 6 min at 250 W, 5 min at 400 W, 8 min at 550 W and then venting for 8 min. The residue resulted from the digestion was then diluted to 100 mL with double distilled water.
Soil sample was collected from Sarcheshme Mine (Kerman, Iran) and digested according to the digestion method mentioned for the sediment sample.

The concentration of the heavy metal ions was determined at optimum conditions in standard reference materials (LKSD-4 and Sea food mix 02–2932). The standard material was digested according to the mentioned procedure for sediment and blank digestion. The pH of the solution was adjusted to 6.4 for the separation and preconcentration of Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II), Zn(II) ions form the solution. Finally, the preconcentration procedure mentioned above was applied to the resulted solutions.

In order to fully understand the effect of the experimental variables that can significantly affect the extraction procedure, individual factors must be considered along with nonlinear effects and interaction terms. The chemometric approach has a rational experimental design, which allows simultaneous variation of all experimental factors, reducing the required time and number of trials which results in the reduction the overall required costs. The Box–Behnken design (BBD) is probably the most widely used experimental design applied for fitting a second-order response surface. This cubic design is characterized by a set of points lying at the midpoint of each edge of a multidimensional cube and center point replicates whereas the ‘missing corners’ help the experimenter to avoid using the combined factor extremes. This property prevents a potential loss of data in those cases [
In this study the StatGraphics plus 5.1 package was used for the analysis of the experimental design data and calculating the predicted responses.
Thermal stability of the magnetic nanocomposite and MOF was evaluated by thermo gravimetric analysis. Figure

shows the thermogravimetry (TG) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) plots for (a) MOF and (b) magnetic nanocomposite (sample D). In DTA plots of MOF, exothermic peaks were observed at 295.1, 326.4, 349.1, and 445.3 °C but in DTA plots of magnetic nanocomposite exothermic peaks were observed at 283.7, 360.5, 409.3 and 433.3 °C. As it is shown in TG plots, the weight loss for MOF was about 72 %, and the remaining 28 % is related to the presence of Cu
in the MOF structure. However, the decrease in weight for magnetic nanocomposite was about 64.4 %. In the remaining 35.6 %, about 28 % is related to Cu
, and about 7.6 % is due to the presence of Fe
ions in the structure of the magnetic nanocomposite. The observations indicate that the formation of magnetic nanocomposite was performed successfully.
The FT-IR spectra of MOF, and magnetic nanocomposite were recorded using KBr pellet method. The advent of the absorption peak due to N–H (3,385 cm
) confirmed the immobilization of MOF by Fe
–DHz. Moreover, elemental analysis showed the presence of 0.211 % S in the structure of the magnetic nanocomposite. This data indicates that Fe
–DHz had been sufficiently immobilized in the structure of magnetic nanocomposite (C: 32.446 %, H: 7.512 %, N: 0.768 %).
To investigate the surface morphology of the MOF and magnetic nanocomposite, the samples were characterized by SEM (Fig.
sample are octahedral with a smooth surface and have an average size of 10 μm (Fig.
). However, surface of the magnetic nanocomposite tends to be rougher after Fe
For further study, MOF and magnetic nanocomposite (sample A, B, C, and D), were investigated by XRD. All of the diffraction peaks for Fe
-DHz immobilized samples B and C show that the sketch of the MOF crystal is well retained even after the modification with Fe
-DHz. It is due to the fact that all diffraction peaks of the immobilized MOF can readily be indexed to [Cu
, supporting information, b, and c). For sample D however, modification of [Cu
-DHz resulted in a loss of crystalline order in the framework. It is evidenced by a significant decrease in diffraction intensities (see Fig. S
d), which is due to the partial decomposition of the crystalline [Cu
]. Although in diffraction peak of sample D, the MOF structure cannot be observed; the presence of Cu and Fe ions in the structure can be determined by FAAS.

The optimization step for the uptake of metal ions on the magnetic nanocomposite was carried out using Box–Behnken design (BBD). Variables affecting the extraction efficiency were chosen: pH, amount of the magnetic nanocomposite, and extraction time. Other parameters involved in the extraction were kept constant, especially the concentration of heavy metal ions (1 mg L
). This design permitted the responses to be modeled by fitting a second-order polynomial, which can be expressed as the following equation:
are the regression coefficients, and Y is the response (removal % or recovery %). The number of experiments (N) is defined by the expression below:
where K is the number of variables and C
is the number of center points [
]. In this study, K and C
were both set at 3, which meant that 15 experiments had to be done. The levels of the factors are listed in Table
. The analysis of variance (ANOVA) results producing the Pareto chart of main and interaction effects which are shown in Fig.

. The standard effect was estimated for computing the t-statistic for each effect. The vertical line on the plot shows statistically significant effects. The bar extracting beyond the line corresponds to the effects that are statistically significant at 95 % confidence level [

]. Furthermore, the positive or negative sign (corresponding to a colored or colorless response) can enhance or reduce the extraction efficiency, respectively, while increasing from the lowest to the highest level set for the specific factor. According to Pareto chart the pH of the solution has the most significant positive effect on the extraction efficiency. The uptake of heavy metal ions increases as the pH increases. In acidic solution, uptake is very low. This observation is due to the protonation of the magnetic nanocomposite active sites especially S and N atoms of dithizone. As the pH increases, the protonation of these active sites decreases and the condition becomes more favorable for complex formation and adsorption of heavy metal ions to the magnetic nanocomposite. The response surface methodology (RSM) (Fig.

) was applied to analysis simultaneous effects of time and pH variables on the response and the two-dimensional contour plot that displayed the interaction between these independent variables. The uptake efficiency of heavy metal ions increased along with the increase in pH while the extraction time had a non-significant positive effect on the extraction of these ions. Extraction time and amount of the magnetic nanocomposite both showed positive but non-significant effect on the extraction efficiency. According to the overall results of the optimization study, the following experimental conditions were chosen: pH, 6.4; extraction time, 13 min; amount of the magnetic nanocomposite, 25 mg.
Experimental variables and levels of the Box Behnken design (BBD)

) Pareto chart of the main effects in the BBD (uptake step). AA, BB and CC are the quadratic effects of the pH, extraction time and amount of magnetic sorbent, respectively. AB, AC and BC are the interaction effects between pH and extraction time; pH and amount of polymer and extraction time and amount of magnetic sorbent, respectively. (
) RSM obtained by plotting of pH
In this work several eluents including HCl, HNO

, NaOH, KCl, thiourea solution and mixture of them were examined as the desorption solvent. Other factors were kept constant during the optimization (pH, 6.4; extraction time, 13 min; amount of the magnetic nanocomposite, 25 mg; eluent volume, 5 mL; elution time, 20 min). Results showed that HCl, HNO
, and NaOH decompose the structure of magnetic nanocomposite but 0.01 mol L
NaOH increases the recovery any structure decomposition. Based on the results, the best quantitative recovery was obtained with 0.01 mol L
NaOH in a thiourea solution as the elution solvent.
Three factors were studied in elution step using experimental design: eluent volume (mL), elution time (min), and concentration of the eluent (mol L

). In these conditions, a response surface design could be done without previously performing a screening design. The BBD was chosen because it requires the least number of experiments (15 run). The data obtained were evaluated by ANOVA. The results of the experimental design were evaluated at 5 % of significance and analyzed by standardized Pareto chart (Fig. S

, supporting information). Based on BBD, volume and concentration of the eluent showed positive and significant effects on the recovery of the heavy metal ions while elution time has a positive but non-significant effect. As Fig. S
shows, eluent volume has the greatest influence on the extraction recovery and a positive effect upon the extraction efficiency. The RSM (Fig. S

, supporting information) was applied to analyze simultaneous effects of the eluent concentration and eluent volume variables on the responses. The extraction efficiency of heavy metal ions increased along with the increase in the eluent concentration and its volume. According to the overall results of the optimization study, the following experimental conditions were chosen: eluent volume, 7.8 mL; elution time, 19 min; and concentration of eluent, 0.9 mol L

In the analysis of real samples, the sample volume is one of the important parameters affecting the preconcentration factor. The breakthrough volume of sample solutions was investigated by dissolving 1 mg of each Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II) and Zn(II) ion in 25, 100, 250, 500, 750, 1,000, 1,100, 1,200, 1,300, 1,400, and 1,500 mL of distilled water. Then the SPE protocol was carried out. The results demonstrated that the dilution effect was not significant for sample volumes of 1,000 mL for Cd(II), 1,100 mL for Zn(II), 1,000 mL for Ni(II), and 1,200 mL for Pb(II) ions on the magnetic nanocomposite.

It was concluded that the simultaneous quantitative recovery of Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II) and Zn(II) ions on the magnetic nanocomposite can be obtained for sample volumes up to 1,000 mL. Thus, the new adsorbent enabling an enrichment factor of 128 was obtained for Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II) and Zn(II) ions.
Effect of the potentially interfering ions

To investigate the effect of the potentially interfering ions found in natural samples, various metal ions were added to 100 mL of a solution containing 0.01 mg Cd(II), 0.01 mg Pb(II), 0.01 mg Ni(II), and 0.01 mg Zn(II) ions. The degree of tolerance for potentially interfering ions is presented in Table

. From the tolerance results, it can be seen that even high levels of the potentially interfering ions has no impact on the preconcentration of Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II) and Zn(II) ions at pH 6.4. So the method could be applied to determine these heavy metal ions in complicated matrix samples.
The tolerance limit of various ions on the determination of heavy metal
Conditions: sample pH = 6.4, sample volume = 100 mL, 100 ng mL
of Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II) and Zn(II) ions sorption, time = 13 min; eluent = 7.8 mL, 0.9 mol L
In order to investigate the enrichment capacity of the magnetic nanocomposite a standard solution containing 100 mg L

of Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II) ions was used. In order to evaluate the maximum enrichment capacity, the initial and equilibrium amounts of heavy metal ions were determined by FAAS. The maximum enrichment capacity is defined as the total amount of heavy metal ions adsorbed per gram of the magnetic nanocomposite. The obtained capacities of the magnetic nanocomposite were found to be 192, 213,178, and 160 mg g
for Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II) ions, respectively.

Under the optimal conditions, calibration curves were constructed for the determination of Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II) ions, according to the mentioned procedure. Linearity was within the range of 1–110 ng mL
for Pb(II) in initial solution. The correlation of determination (r
) was 0.997 for Cd(II), 0.996 for Zn(II), 0.997 for Ni(II), and 0.998 for Pb(II) ions. The limit of detection is defined as LOD = 3S
is the standard deviation of 10 replicate blank signals and m is the slope of the calibration curve after preconcentration. For a sample volume of 500 mL, it was found to be 0.12 ng mL
for Pb(II) ions. The precision of the method for a standard solution containing 50 ng mL
= 5) was evaluated as the relative standard deviation (RSD%) and was found to be 3.6, 4.3, 4.7, and 3.9 %, for Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II) ions respectively.

The concentrations of Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II) ions obtained by current method were compared to the exact concentration of these ions in the standard reference materials. For this reason, the concentration of the heavy metal ions was determined at optimum conditions in standard reference materials (LKSD-4 and Sea food mix 02–2932). As it can be seen in Table

, good correlation was achieved between the estimated content by the present method and reference materials. Therefore, the magnetic nanocomposite can be used as a reliable solid phase for the extraction and determination of Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II) ions in various samples.
Determination of heavy metal ion recovery in certified reference material
Determination of Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II) ions in various real samples

Since natural samples have complex matrices, non-specific background absorption is always caused by interfering species of the sample matrix. To reduce this undesirable effect, the magnetic nanocomposite was applied for the selective extraction of Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II) ions in pH 6.4. Table
shows the Cd(II), Pb(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II) ions recovery in various real samples which in all cases, were almost quantitative.
Analysis of heavy metal ions in different real samples

A simple, fast, reproducible, and selective solid-phase extraction procedure, based on metal organic framework (magnetic MOF-DHz nanocomposite), for determining of cadmium, zinc, nickel, and lead ions has been developed. In comparison with other solid-phases, the magnetic nanocomposite has the advantages of high enrichment capacity, low limit of detection, and high enrichment factor (Table S

, supporting information). Other advantages of this method are: (1) low time-consumption due to the magnetically-assisted separation of the adsorbent and higher surface area; therefore, satisfactory results can be achieved by using fewer amounts of the adsorbents. Due to the relatively high preconcentration factor, trace amounts of heavy metal at ng mL
levels in high-volume samples can be quantified by the magnetic nanocomposite.
